Fibonacci Numbers
Let's Learn

Concept of Countability in Algorithms



We take the following factors about an algorithm into account before solving:

  • Accuracy
  • Time Complexity
  • Methods to increase efficiency (make better)


Analysis of Fibonacci Sequence:

  • Sequence :
    \[ F_n = \begin{cases} F_{n-1} + F_{n-2} &\text{if } n>1 \\ 1 &\text{if } n=1 \\ 0 &\text{if }n=0 \end{cases} \]
  • Fibonacci numbers grow as powers of 2. \[ \large F_n \approx 2^{0.694n}$ \]


    • Algorithm 1 (Exponential):

    There are computational problems that computer cannot solve.
    We recursively calculate $fib(n)$ as in the following pseudo code: 
     
function fibonacci(n):
    if n = 0:
        return 0
    if n = 1:
        return 1
    return fib1(n − 1) + fib1(n − 2)


    Algorithm 2 (Polynomial algorithm):

    We convert the above code to iterative method which eliminates overlapping computations thus reducing time complexity 
     
function fibonacci(n):
    if n = 0 :
         return 0
    Create array F[n];
    F[0]=0, F[1]=1;
    for i = 2 to n:
        F[i] = F[i-1] + F[i-2];
    return F[n];

    The addition is O(n) steps and loop runs n times
    Hence Time Complexity : \[ O(n^2) \]


    Algorithm 3 (using matrices):

    We notice the following patters to calculate fib(n):
    \[ \begin{pmatrix} F_1\\ F_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} . \begin{pmatrix} F_0\\ F_1 \end{pmatrix} \]
    Generalizing above:
    \[ \begin{pmatrix} F_n\\ F_{n+1} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^n . \begin{pmatrix} F_0\\ F_1 \end{pmatrix} \]
    Time Complexity = O(M(n)log(n)) where M : Time to multiply 2 n bit numbers


    Algorithm 4: (Direct Formula) :


    \[ F_n = \frac 1 {\sqrt{5}}. \bigg(\frac {1+{\sqrt{5}}} 2\bigg)^n - \frac 1 {\sqrt{5}}. \bigg(\frac {1-{\sqrt{5}}} 2\bigg)^n \]
    Problem: There are accuracy issues due to irrational parts, also large arrays are required to multiply digits accurately.
